statement.title: Problem Description
statement.content:
We all know a+b=c,but now there is a new rule in equations:
if a>b,then it's equal to [>c];
if a=b,then it's equal to [=c];
if a<b,then it's equal to [<c];
a sample:

1+1=[=2]
2+0=[>2]
0+2=[<2]
1+2=[<3]

and [>c] > [=c] > [<c].
For every [n],
[n+1] > [n] >[n-1].

statement.title: Input
statement.content: The input consists of T cases.The first line of the input contains only positive integer T (0<T<=100).Then follows the cases.Each case begins with a line containing exactly one integer N (0<N<=10000).Then there are N lines, each with two integers a and b (0<a,b<2^31-1).

statement.title: Output
statement.content: For each case, calculate each value of a+b(as a+b=[?]) and output a+b=[?] in descending order sorted by [?]. If there exists some pair of a,b whose order can not be determined by the rules above, output them with the order of the input. A blank line should be printed after each case.

statement.title: Source
statement.content: 2011 Multi-University Training Contest 4 - Host by SDU
